text: If package A uses a version of package B (call it B1) and your project environment uses another version (call it B2) - is this a problem? I ask because I thought it shouldn't be, but I've noticed that the behaviour of the CSV changes (read "breaks") depending on my project environment at times

elements.text: If package A uses a version of package B (call it B1) and your project environment uses another version (call it B2) - is this a problem? I ask because I thought it shouldn't be, but I've noticed that the behaviour of the CSV changes (read "breaks") depending on my project environment at times

text: Yes, Julia will only load a single version of a package in a given environment. Otherwise there could be conflicts if package A exposes the version of B it uses.

elements.text: Yes, Julia will only load a single version of a package in a given environment. Otherwise there could be conflicts if package A exposes the version of B it uses.

text: Thanks! but this is not the case for different packages right? So if package A uses B1 and package C uses B2 that's fine right?

elements.text: Thanks! but this is not the case for different packages right? So if package A uses B1 and package C uses B2 that's fine right?

text: No it's the same, because packages could exchange objects from package B.

elements.text: No it's the same, because packages could exchange objects from package B.

text: Ah, ok. That clears things up a lot.

elements.text: Ah, ok. That clears things up a lot.
